Situation1: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: An urgent directive from the coordinator outlines mandatory procedures that must be followed to avoid shutting down the service.
Story: I sat on the edge of my bed, phone pressed to my ear, listening to my boyfriend’s shaky voice as he tried to process the loss of his brother. He needed me—he said he didn’t want to be alone, that he just needed someone to sit with him, to listen, to hold his hand. My heart ached for him, and I promised I’d be there soon. As I hung up, my phone buzzed again. It was a message from the volunteer coordinator: “All volunteers must report in person tonight. We have to implement new safety procedures immediately or risk shutting down the shelter. No exceptions.” I stared at the screen, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing down on me. My boyfriend needed me more than ever, but so did the people at the shelter—and if I didn’t show up, I’d be letting down the team and the people who depended on us. My chest tightened as I tried to figure out how I could possibly be in two places at once, torn between love and responsibility, knowing that whatever I chose, someone would be left needing me.
